column4: U.S. charges ousted Hollywood executive with defrauding pandemic loan program, BlackRock fund
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - U.S. prosecutors have charged the recently ousted owner of a Hollywood movie distributor with defrauding a federal coronavirus emergency relief program and a BlackRock Inc investment fund, including to pay for a Beverly Hills mansion and other luxuries.
column6: Prosecutors said William Sadleir, 66, diverted much of the $1.7 million of loans he received on May 1 from the Paycheck Protection Program for personal expenses.
column7: He allegedly did this after falsely telling JPMorgan Chase & Co and the Small Business Administration the funds were meant for his former company Aviron Group, which had terminated him in December and where he has no current role.
column8: The PPP was meant “to help small businesses stay afloat during the financial crisis, and we will act swiftly against those who abuse the program for their own personal gain,” U.S. Attorney Nick Hanna in Los Angeles said in a statement.
column9: Sadleir was also accused of having previously induced the closed-end BlackRock Multi-Sector Income Trust Fund to invest $75 million in Aviron to support its films.
column10: Prosecutors said he then created a sham company to conceal his use of the money, and assumed the fake identity “Amanda Stevens” to communicate by email with the BlackRock fund about its investment.
column11: In a related civil case, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission said Sadleir’s “lavish lifestyle” also included a $127,000 Tesla.
column12: A lawyer for Sadleir could not immediately be identified. A BlackRock spokesman declined to comment.
column13: Aviron’s films have included Halle Berry’s “Kidnap” and Matthew McConaughey and Anne Hathaway’s “Serenity.”
column14: The BlackRock fund had $574 million of assets as of May 21, and normally invests most assets in debt and loans. It sued Sadleir for fraud in a New York state court in December.
column15: Sadleir faces up to 124 years in prison if convicted on all charges.

column4: U.S. charges Hollywood film distributor with defrauding BlackRock fund
column5: NEW YORK, May 22 (Reuters) - U.S. prosecutors on Friday charged the founder and former owner of a Hollywood movie production and distribution company with defrauding a BlackRock Inc investment fund out of about$14 million to pay for luxuries including a Beverly Hills mansion.
column6: William Sadleir, 66, of Beverly Hills, California, was charged with two counts of wire fraud and one count of aggravated identity theft after inducing the closed-end BlackRock Multi-Sector Income Trust Fund to invest $75 million in his Aviron Group.
column7: Sadleir allegedly promised BlackRock its money would support his films, including through the purchase of $27 million in pre-paid media credits, or “up fronts,” with the GroupM affiliate of WPP Plc, the world’s largest advertising company.
column8: But prosecutors said Sadleir created the sham company GroupM Media Services LLC and a related bank account to make his activities look legitimate.
column9: They said he then posed as fake GroupM Media employee “Amanda Stevens” to communicate by email with the BlackRock fund about its investment.
column10: Authorities including the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, which filed related civil charges, said Sadleir also spent embezzled money to remodel Aviron’s offices and buy a $127,000 Tesla, to help fund his “lavish lifestyle.”
column11: Sadleir’s lawyer in the criminal case could not immediately be identified. A lawyer who has represented Sadleir in civil litigation had no immediate comment. A BlackRock spokesman declined to comment.
column12: The BlackRock fund had $574 million of assets as of May 21. It normally invests at least 80% of assets in debt and loans.
column13: Sadleir was removed from Aviron’s helm after the BlackRock fund filed a fraud lawsuit against him and the company in a New York state court in Manhattan, court papers show.
column14: The wire fraud charges carry maximum 20 years prison terms.
column15: The criminal case is U.S. v. Sadleir, U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York, No. 20-mag-05114. (Reporting by Jonathan Stempel in New York)
